Description: Wheel-made oil-lamp with a low-placed carination, and a narrow, inward-sloping rim. The oil-lamp stands on a flat resting-surface, probably fettled rather than turned. Red clay; nozzle blackened by smoke. Nozzle was possibly painted black.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Unprovenanced parallel from Egypt, dated from the 6th to 5th century BC or 'considerably later' (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q514, see also 6th century import Q374). Copy or variant of Greek type found at Athens (Howland 1958, Type 16). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals, Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.18) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4835 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
